doc.title: Metals & Mining: LatAm Copper ( ) : Strong Peru data; Chile Sees Production Declines
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Metals Mining LatAm Copper June Data Strong Peru data Chile Sees Production DeclinesMetals Mining LatAm Copper June Data_2025-08-28

passages.text: June's copper production was strong Peru \((+7\% y / y; +4\% m / m)\) , weak in Chile \((- 7\% y / y; - 13\% m / m)\) and broadly stable in Mexico \((- 1\% y / y; - 1\% m / m)\) .

In Chile, production declined at Escondida \((- 33\% y / y; - 42\% m / m)\) was the main reason for Chile lower output in June, followed by Collahuasi \((- 11\% m / m; - 29\% y / y)\) and Codelco's mines \((- 8\% m / m, + 17\% y / y)\) . GSe for Chile production growth in FY25 is \(- 1\% y / y\) vs. \(+3\% y / y\) YTD. Following the incident at the El Teniente (Codelco) underground mine on July 31, production is now expected at 316kt in 2025 \((- 28kt / 8\%\) below 1H25 annualized production).

In Peru, production increased by \(4\% m / m\) driven by Cerro Verde and Antamina. On a y/y basis, production growth of \(7\% y / y\) was driven by Las Bambas and Chinalco, while it was weak for Antamina. GSe for Peru production growth in FY25 is \(+2\%\) y/y vs. \(+4\%\) y/y YTD.
In Mexico, June copper production was broadly stable, declining by \(1\%\) both y/y and m/m.

In Brazil, copper concentrate shipments for July more than doubled m/m and soared by \(55\%\) y/y due to strong shipments from Salobo and Sossego, while Ero's Tucuma had no volumes. GSe for Brazil production growth in FY25 is \(+13\%\) y/y vs. \(+7\%\) y/y YTD.

Please see below for this month's key highlights on copper, including: 1) Global EV sales up \(4\% m / m\) and \(13\%\) y/y in June; 2) Domestic appliances data robust momentum in July; 3) GS's China Basic Materials team monthly survey tracking orderbooks of downstream and basic materials producers, indicating that for copper the orderbook was flat to down MoM, weaker than normal seasonality.

Chile's June copper production decreased \(7\%\) y/y and \(13\%\) m/m. According to Cochilco, the Chilean Copper Commission, total copper production decreased \(31kt y / y\) and \(64kt m / m\) to 419kt. Production dip at Escondida mine \((- 33\% y / y; - 42\% m / m)\) was the main culprit for the country's sequentially lower output in June, followed by Collahuasi \((- 11\% m / m; - 29\% y / y)\) and Codelco's mines \((- 8\% m / m, + 17\% y / y)\) . Following the incident at the El Teniente (Codelco) underground

mine on July 31, production is now expected at 316kt in 2025 (- 28kt/8% below 1H25 annualized production for the mine).
Exhibit 1:Chile Copper Production by Mine
Exhibit 2: LTM Chile Copper Production (kt)
Exhibit 3: Monthly Chile Copper Production (kt)

Peru-Peru's June copper production increased by \(7\%\) y/y and \(4\%\) m/m. Peru's Ministry of Mines and Energy (MINEM) reported copper production increasing 15kt y/y in June, reaching 22kt. The m/m increase was driven by Cerro Verde (+26%) and Antamina (+1%), while on a y/y basis, production growth was driven by Las Bambas and Chinalco. GSe for Peru production growth in FY25 is \(+2\%\) y/y vs. \(+4\%\) YTD y/y.
Exhibit 4: Peru Copper Production by Mine
Exhibit 5: LTM Peru Copper Production (kt)
Exhibit 6: Monthly Peru Copper Production (kt)

Mexico's June copper production mostly stable \((- 1\%\) both y/y and m/m).Mexico's National System of Statistical and Geographical Information (INEGI) reported a small production decline of 1kt y/y, reaching 57kt. YTD production is declining by \(- 2\%\) y/y.
Exhibit 7: Mexico Copper Production by Mine
Exhibit 8: LTM Mexico Copper Production (kt)
Exhibit 9: Monthly Mexico Copper Production (kt)

BrazilBrazil's July copper exports increased \(55\%\) y/y and \(131\%\) m/m. Brazil's Foreign trade department (SECEX) reported that copper exports increased by \(55\%\) y/y and \(131\%\) m/m in July, reaching 181kt. The y/y increase was driven by stronger exports
from Salobo, Sossego and Caraiba. While Tucumã remained at zero shipments.
Exhibit 10: Brazil Copper Exports by Mine
Exhibit 11: LTM Brazil Copper Exports (kt)
Exhibit 12: Monthly Brazil Copper Exports (kt)

Global Global EV sales increased \(4\%\) m/m and \(13\%\) y/y in June. According to Marklines, global electric vehicle sales reached 1,483k units in June, up \(13\%\) y/y. EV sales penetration reached \(27\%\) ( \(1\%\) total vehicle sales in the month), up 0.6pp m/m and + 2.8pp y/y. EVs currently represent \(3\%\) of total copper demand, but are one of the key growth drivers for the metal.
Exhibit 13: Global electric vehicle sales (mn units) and EV penetration (%)
Domestic appliances data continued robust momentum in July (by GS China

Consumer team). As shown from both robust retail and ex- factory shipment growth: 1) NBS home appliances and electronics retail sales grew by \(+29\%\) in July, slightly down from \(+32\%\) yoy in Jun; 2) AC domestic ex- factory shipment growth moderated slightly to \(+14\%\) yoy in July, but above previous production plan compiled by IOL. The above said, we expect domestic growth to sequentially moderate going forward as comp base will start to elevate from Aug/Sep when national trade- in stimulus kicked in last year, yet we don't expect significant yoy decline as demand is still supported by orderly stimulus execution. The pace of exports decline remained largely stable in July. Per customs data, appliances export value/volume declined by \(4\% /5\%\) yoy in July, sequentially improved from \(9\% /9\%\) yoy decline in Jun. AC exports shipment declined by a similar pace in July compared to June (- 15% yoy), yet better than the previous production plan. In the coming months, we still expect pressure on industry exports growth considering a high base last year and leading players' efforts to localize production overseas, yet we remain constructive on leading players' potential to gain shares especially in emerging markets (vs DMs as durables demand indicators such as consumer sentiment and property data still haven't shown meaningful improvements). Click here for the full report.
Exhibit 14: China white goods exports growth moderated, with stable/slightly lower EU/US consumer sentiment into July/Aug
Source: IOL, University of Michigan

Exhibit 15: Domestic growth showed further strength for both retail sales and ex-factory shipment in July though moderated from Jun, while exports decline remained largely stable Appliances data dashboard
Source: AVC, IOL, NBS, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

End- user orderbooks were stable MoM as of mid- August. Demand remains uninspiring, with continued weak trend in infrastructure starts and renewables, while others were mostly stagnant. However, anti- involution related supply work has led to broad- based domestic price hikes in upstream commodities, with lithium and met coal leading the pack, and suggest the average prices of main commodities has moved up by \(2 - 13\%\) sequentially in August, the 1st time since Apr- 2021. Supply policies are still in early stages but suggest positive direction of travel: including the new safety standards and control on overproduction of coal, proposed technical specifications for monitoring cement production, and clean- ups in lithium mining licenses. On the other hand, the improved steel margin has set back the steel production cuts, while higher lithium price to trigger the flexibility of supply globally, in our view. For Copper, GS China Basic Materials team channel checks with major fabricators suggest that the orderbook was flat to down MoM, weaker than normal seasonality. High- frequency industry fabrication data suggests current end demand for copper is running at \(6\%\) lower yoy for August. Click here for the full report.
Exhibit 16: Channel checks - basic materials orderbook trend
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 17: Channel checks - net inventory levels and changes
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research (proprietary survey)

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global cover, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when

Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
